entry.title: Are the Ways of Seeing Francesca Woodman and Edith Gowin the same?
entry.summary: Francesca Woodman's work is on exhibition in Stockholm. I look at her photography, and felt that I had to reread parts of John Berger's ways of seeing.

a.title: In the background are two of Francesca Woodman's Caryatids. There are a large sample of photobooks about Francesca on the table in the foreground

div.p: Francesca Woodman took her life 1981 at 22 years of age. By then she had become a serious, hardworking and extremely skilled artistic photographer. She had started her exploration of art photography when she was 13. When considering these early works, we are talking of a serious endeavour of a precocious, talented teenager, not a child's play.

Much of her work is self portraiture, and often she portrays herself naked. There are several female photographers who have earned well-deserved fame for (among other things) photographing naked humans, such as Imogen Cunningham and Ruth Bernard. They both depicted naked women, but as far as I know, neither Cunningham nor Bernard portrayed themselves, with or without clothes.

Francesca Woodman's work is on exhibition at Moderna Museet, Stockholm. According to Anna Tellgren, the curator, the reason why Woodman used herself as model was just practical1. She was there when she needed a model. The cost was lower and there were no problems with model release contracts. I am sure there is more to than that. Since Francesca Woodman, Cindy Sherman and several contemporaries, the interest in this kind of self-portraiture has increased and is now a fairly common genre. I think it is much more common among women than men. This text is about my attempt to understand that difference.
Emmett Gowin from Landscape Stories on Vimeo.

The only things I know about Edith Gowin is that she is a beautiful woman and that her husband is photographer Emmet Gowin. He is a well known photographer who earned much of his fame for his portraits of his often scantily clad or naked wife. The two have now celebrated their golden wedding anniversary since several years. In the interviews you find of them (for example) YouTube they seem to be still a loving couple. However, it might be that Emmet don't take as many photographs of Edith now as he did 40-50 years ago.

Emmet Gowin is not alone. There are other husband photographers of taking photos of their wives that go far beyond the average such as Alfred Stieglitz (1864-1946) portraits of Georgia O'Keeffe (1887-1986) which arose from an intense love story and relation. 2 Edward Weston shot countless of nudes, of which, according to Robert Adams, most are fairly uninteresting:

p.em: With the exception of two full length nudes of Tina Modotti and five of Charis Wilson in the Oceano dunes (not many, considering the number of nudes Weston took), the pictures that supposedly resulted from Weston's love for his subjects are relative to the rest of his life's work, unsuccessful; they are cold to the point of being dead.

div.p: These photos are to be found on many web sites. Suitable searches in Google images:

ul.li: Edward Westons portraits of Charis Wilson

div.p: Many photos of lesser artists than Weston Stieglitz and Gowin deserve even less praise. It might be that most such pictures shouldn't really have been taken.

One of the best, earliest and still extremely influential theoretical analyses of the nude in western art is in Ways of seeing by John Berger3. His arguments can be summarized in contrasting statements. For example:

tr.td: Women watch themselves being looked at.
To be naked is to be oneself
To be nude is to be seen as naked by others and yet not recognized for oneself

div.p: Berger argues that to be naked is to be without disguise, and to be nude is to be on display, to carry an disguise without clothes; to be condemned to never be naked. I could go on giving examples Berger's treatment. What interests me is not the mainstream though. Not all those hundreds of thousands of nude oil paintings and perhaps millions of photographs that fit the cliches described. I'm rather interested in those few houndreds exceptions that do not.
